name: Voice Input
description: Child speaks their answer; transcribed by AI. Essential for pre-readers and emerging readers. Always available as fallback regardless of year group.
ui_notes: Large microphone button with waveform animation. Playback button so child can hear their answer before submitting. Auto-submit after 2 seconds of silence option.
agent_prompt: Use single voiced questions only. Do not display the question text — speak it. Provide visual microphone affordance. Confirm transcription back before evaluating. Accept phonetic approximations for subject vocabulary.

name: Multiple Choice — 2 Options
description: Binary forced choice between 2 illustrated or text options. Both should be plausible. Ideal for pre-readers with illustrated options.
ui_notes: Two large full-width buttons. Options can be images, icons, or large text (min 24pt). No radio buttons — full-area tap targets.
agent_prompt: Offer exactly 2 options. Both should be meaningfully plausible — avoid obvious distractors. Use images rather than text where possible. Frame as a binary distinction (odd/even, living/non-living, more/less than).

name: Multiple Choice — 3 Options
description: Choose 1 from 3 options. Standard format for Y1 onwards. Options can mix text and illustration.
ui_notes: Three clearly spaced buttons. Illustrations optional from Y3 onwards. Options stacked vertically on mobile.
agent_prompt: Provide 1 correct answer and 2 plausible distractors. Distractors should represent common misconceptions, not random wrong answers. Label A/B/C only if children are Y3+.

name: Multiple Choice — 4 Options
description: Standard 4-option multiple choice. The default format for Y4 onwards. Distractors should represent genuine misconceptions.
ui_notes: 4 options in 2×2 grid (tablet) or stacked (mobile). A/B/C/D labels visible.
agent_prompt: 1 correct answer + 3 distractors. Each distractor should address a specific, documented misconception from the curriculum domain. Explain why the distractor is wrong in post-answer feedback.

name: Multiple Choice — 5 Options (with None/All)
description: 5-option multiple choice, can include 'None of the above' or 'All of the above'. Appropriate for Y5+ to increase cognitive demand.
ui_notes: Stacked list with A–E labels. 'None of the above' should appear last if used. Do not use in time-limited contexts.
agent_prompt: Use when curriculum content warrants nuanced discrimination. 'None of the above' is a high-cognitive-demand option — use selectively, not as a default filler. Confirm the distractor set addresses documented misconceptions.

name: Text Input — Single Word
description: Type or speak a single-word answer. Suitable from Y3 where keyboard proficiency is emerging.
ui_notes: Single-line input field, auto-capitalise off, spellcheck on but answer accepted if phonetically close. Voice fallback always available.
agent_prompt: Accept near-miss spellings (within 2 Levenshtein edits of the correct answer). Do not penalise spelling errors unless spelling is the assessed skill. Provide word-length hint (e.g. _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ) if child makes 2 failed attempts.

name: Text Input — Short Phrase
description: Type 3–10 words. Short-answer format for Y3–Y5 factual and explanatory questions.
ui_notes: Single-line input with 40-char hint width. Show character count if near the upper bound. Voice fallback available.
agent_prompt: Do not require perfect sentence structure at this level. Accept key terms and partial explanations. Use semantic similarity matching, not exact string match. Provide a sentence starter if child stalls (e.g. 'The answer begins with...').

name: Text Input — Full Sentence
description: Type a complete sentence (10–25 words). Suitable from Y4 for explanation, inference, and analysis tasks.
ui_notes: Multiline text area (2 lines). Word count guide. Sentence starter scaffold available on demand.
agent_prompt: Evaluate sentence for meaning, not surface grammar. Provide a structural scaffold prompt if blank after 30 seconds: 'Try starting with [X] because...' or 'I think [X] because [Y]'. In feedback, show a model answer alongside the child's response.

name: Text Input — Paragraph
description: Extended writing response, 30–80 words. Appropriate for Y5+ analytical and evaluative tasks.
ui_notes: Multiline text area (4 lines visible). Word count displayed. Paragraph planner scaffold available. Autosave in progress.
agent_prompt: Structure evaluation around: claim (present?), evidence (cited?), reasoning (logical?). Use a 3-point rubric internally. Feedback should address each dimension. Do not focus on spelling or grammar unless that is the assessed skill.

name: Code Input
description: Type or edit code snippets. For Computing/Computational Thinking tasks from Y6 onwards.
ui_notes: Monospaced font, syntax highlighting, auto-indent. Run/execute button if environment supports it. Line numbers visible.
agent_prompt: Provide code scaffolds with comments indicating what to complete. Never show the full solution in the scaffold. Check logic, not just syntax. Feedback should explain why the code works or fails conceptually.

name: Drag and Drop — Place on Target
description: Drag objects to a target location (e.g., place the number on the number line, sort animals into habitats). Fundamental interaction from Y1.
ui_notes: Large drag handles (min 48×48px touch target). Clear snap-to-target zones. Undo button always visible. Accessibility: keyboard-navigable alternative.
agent_prompt: Use when placement reveals understanding (e.g., ordering on number line, sorting into Venn diagram). Items should be clearly distinguishable by colour/shape. Limit to 6 draggable items maximum per screen for Y1-Y3.

name: Drag to Reorder
description: Drag items in a list to arrange them in correct sequence (events, steps in a process, ascending/descending order).
ui_notes: Drag handles visible (≡ icon). Items snap to position. After submit, animate correct order if child was wrong. Maximum 8 items.
agent_prompt: Use for chronological ordering, process sequences, or ranked comparisons. Provide 4–6 items for Y4–Y5, up to 8 for Y6+. After incorrect submission, show correct order with brief explanation of the sequencing logic.

name: Drag to Categorise
description: Drag items into labelled category buckets. Used for classification tasks across subjects.
ui_notes: Category buckets clearly outlined. Items can live in multiple buckets if the classification supports it (e.g., Venn diagram). Drop zones highlight on hover/drag over.
agent_prompt: Limit to 2–3 categories for Y3, up to 4–5 for Y5+. Confirm whether items are mutually exclusive or can belong to multiple categories. In feedback, explain the classification principle, not just the correct placement.

name: Sentence Assembly
description: Drag word tiles into order to construct a correct sentence. Used in literacy tasks from Y2.
ui_notes: Word tiles presented in a shuffled bank at the bottom. Target area at the top. Punctuation tiles included. Font size min 18pt. Tiles snap to position.
agent_prompt: Keep target sentences to 5–10 words for Y2–Y3, up to 15 words for Y4+. Include one or two plausible alternative orderings that are grammatically acceptable (flag these as also correct). Post-assembly, read the sentence aloud to the child.

name: Matching Pairs
description: Draw connections between matching items in two columns (term/definition, cause/effect, word/image).
ui_notes: Two columns with tappable/clickable items. Lines drawn between matched pairs. Colour-coded lines for clarity. Maximum 6 pairs per screen.
agent_prompt: Limit to 4–5 pairs for Y3–Y4, up to 6–8 pairs for Y5+. Distractors should be near-misses (similar terms, not obviously unrelated). After matching, display all correct pairs simultaneously before moving on.

name: Image Annotation — Tap to Label
description: Tap regions on an image (diagram, map, organism) to label them from a provided list or freetext. Used from Y2 for science diagrams and geography maps.
ui_notes: High-resolution diagrams required. Tap targets shown as pulsing circles. Labels can be drag-placed or chosen from dropdown. Pin/label reveal animation on correct placement.
agent_prompt: Use for anatomy diagrams, food webs, geographical features, historical artefacts. Hotspot targets should be minimum 44×44px. Provide labelling list for Y2–Y4 (select from provided terms). Open labelling (typed) for Y5+.

name: Number Line — Drag Marker
description: Drag a marker along a number line to indicate a value or position. Used for estimation, ordering, fraction placement, negative numbers.
ui_notes: Labelled endpoints, optional intermediate markers. Snap-to-integer or snap-to-fraction-denominator mode. Shows value tooltip as user drags. Landscape orientation preferred.
agent_prompt: Specify the number range and expected precision (integer, 0.5, 0.1, fraction). For fractions, display both the fractional position and decimal equivalent below the line. Use after teaching formal notation to reinforce conceptual placement.

name: Bus Stop Division (Short Division Layout)
description: Step-through formal short division algorithm using the bus stop visual layout. Child works digit by digit, guided through each step.
ui_notes: Render the bus stop symbol (divisor outside bracket, dividend inside, quotient above). Highlight the active digit. Show carried remainder visually. Step-validation after each digit entered.
agent_prompt: Walk the child through each step: (1) How many times does [divisor] go into the first digit? (2) What is the remainder? (3) Carry remainder to next digit. Provide immediate validation after each digit entered. Never show the answer — guide the algorithm step by step. This is Y4–Y6 content aligned to NC formal written methods.

name: Column Addition (Formal Written Method)
description: Formal column addition with carrying. Child enters digits in the correct column positions. Includes carrying mechanism.
ui_notes: Column layout with H/T/U headers. Carrying row above. Input fields in answer row. Carrying digit input in small field above the column. Colour-coded column headers.
agent_prompt: Provide the addends; child completes the sum digit by digit. Start with the units column. Prompt carrying explicitly. Correct individual digit errors immediately before child moves to the next column.

name: Column Subtraction (Formal Written Method with Exchanging)
description: Formal column subtraction with exchange (borrowing). Step-validated digit entry with visual exchange animation.
ui_notes: Exchange shown visually with crossing out and superscript. Column layout with clear exchange area. Animate the exchange when child requests it.
agent_prompt: Start from the units column. When exchange is needed, prompt: 'You need to exchange 1 ten for 10 ones — can you do that now?' Show the exchange animation. Validate after each digit. Common error: subtracting the smaller from larger (3-8 written as 8-3) — detect and correct immediately.

name: Fraction Visualiser (Bar / Pizza / Set Model)
description: Interactive visual model for fractions. Switch between bar model, pizza model, and set (counters) model. Child manipulates to explore equivalence and comparison.
ui_notes: Model selector tabs (bar / pizza / set). Denominator and numerator sliders. Side-by-side comparison mode. Equivalence line annotation. Display fractional notation alongside visual.
agent_prompt: Use in productive failure setup: ask child to compare 1/2 and 2/5 before providing tools, then reveal the visualiser. Encourage exploration of multiple models. Connect visual to symbolic: 'What does the 5 at the bottom tell you about the pizza?' Link to real-world contexts (sharing food, folding paper).

name: Area Model (Grid / Array for Multiplication)
description: Visual grid model for multiplication and expanded notation. Used to develop understanding of distributive property before formal algorithm.
ui_notes: Gridded rectangle. Child enters width and height values. Grid fills to show array. Partition lines for expanded method. Colour sections by place value (hundreds/tens/ones).
agent_prompt: Use after introducing multiplication concept, before formal long multiplication algorithm. Ask child to estimate the area first (productive failure). Then reveal the model. Connect: 'The grid shows us that 23 × 14 is the same as (20 × 14) + (3 × 14) — can you see that in the grid?'

name: Place Value Blocks (Dienes / Base-10)
description: Manipulate virtual Base-10 (Dienes) blocks: unit cubes, tens rods, hundreds flats. Used for place value, addition, subtraction, and exchange concepts.
ui_notes: Drag blocks from a bank. Grouping animation: 10 units → 1 ten rod. Three-column display (H / T / U). Counter displays total value. Exchange button.
agent_prompt: Use when introducing or consolidating place value, regrouping, or exchanging concepts. Ask child to 'show me 347 using the blocks' before any formal task. When exchange is needed in addition, prompt them to group: 'You have 13 ones — what can you do with those?' Connect blocks to abstract notation.

name: Text Highlight and Select
description: Highlight a passage in a reading extract to identify evidence, inference clues, or key vocabulary. Used from Y4 for comprehension tasks.
ui_notes: Click/tap and drag to select text. Multiple highlight colours for different purposes (e.g., yellow=evidence, blue=inference clue). Annotation popup on highlight. Highlights persist across the question set.
agent_prompt: Instruct child to highlight specific evidence before asking them to explain it. 'Find the part of the text that tells you [X]'. After highlight, ask: 'Why does that part of the text show us [X]?' Multiple colours allow tracking evidence, vocabulary, and inference clues separately.

name: Text Annotation — Add Comment
description: Add typed or voiced comments to highlighted text passages. Used for literary analysis and close reading from Y5.
ui_notes: Comment bubble appears on highlight. Short text field (1–2 sentences). Comment anchored to selected text. Multiple annotations visible simultaneously with toggle.
agent_prompt: Use for PEE (Point, Evidence, Explain) structures. Scaffold with column headers: 'What does this word suggest?' / 'What is the effect on the reader?'. Show annotations from a model reader alongside child's own for comparison.

name: Pattern Discovery — I Notice / I Wonder
description: Open-ended discovery mode where child clicks 'I notice...' or 'I wonder...' buttons to record observations before instruction. Used to activate prior knowledge in productive failure sequences.
ui_notes: Two large buttons: 'I notice...' (yellow) and 'I wonder...' (blue). Each click opens a voice/text input. Child's observations collected in a scrollable list. No right/wrong feedback during this phase.
agent_prompt: This is the productive failure activation phase — do NOT correct or evaluate observations during discovery. Say 'That is interesting, what else do you notice?' to all responses. After the discovery phase, connect the child's actual observations to the canonical concept: 'You noticed [X] — that is the [Y] pattern.'

name: Inference Task — Socratic Questioning
description: Guided Socratic question chain where the AI asks a sequence of progressively more specific questions to scaffold inference from text or data. Used from Y4.
ui_notes: Conversation-style display. Child's response followed by next question. Source text/image visible on the same screen. Progress indicator shows depth into the question chain.
agent_prompt: Question sequence: (1) What do you notice / see? (2) What does that tell you? (3) Why do you think that? (4) What would need to be different for your answer to change? Never affirm or deny until the end of the chain. Final step: 'You inferred [X] correctly because [Y] — the text didn't say it directly, but the clues were [Z].'

name: Compare and Contrast Table
description: Structured table for comparing two or more concepts, events, or organisms. Child populates cells. Used from Y5 for analysis tasks.
ui_notes: 2–3 column table with labelled rows (criteria). Cell text input (1–2 sentences). 'Similarity' and 'Difference' row types. Export/print of completed table.
agent_prompt: Pre-populate comparison criteria (rows) — do not ask child to identify criteria at Y5; provide them. Y6+ can be given blank criteria rows to identify. After completion, prompt: 'Looking at your table, what is the most important difference?' to prompt synthesis beyond recall.

name: Rhythm Analyser — Mark Stress Pattern
description: Tap syllables in a poem or text to mark them as stressed (/) or unstressed (u). Reveals iambic, trochaic, and free verse patterns. Y6 English specialist tool.
ui_notes: Text displayed syllable by syllable (split automatically). Tap to toggle stressed/unstressed. Stress marks display above syllables. Play button reads the marked rhythm aloud.
agent_prompt: First play the poem aloud (TTS with expressive prosody). Ask child to clap along before interacting with the tool. Then ask: 'Which syllables are stronger — tap those to mark them.' After marking, compare to a canonical stress pattern and discuss where the child's interpretation differs.
